13332121.content:
Cody, it turned out, was emphatically NOT from South Barkalow. He had joined the Yogafit staff in North Barkalow as a preventative health care specialist right out of college. "I was pretty ambitious. Had a full head of hair in those days, too," he said, "if you can believe that!"

Lisa laughed with him. How sad this man was. He couldn't have been more than thirty.

"Anyway," Cody continued, "my boss didn't like how motivated I was. You know how it is with government programs. Don't rock the boat. I called him out on that--biggest mistake of my life. The next day, he told me that since I was so anxious to get people in shape, he'd transfer me down to S.B. I'd never actually been here before--the roads from North B. don't run directly the South--the ones that did got blocked off in the nineteen-nineties--and if you can believe it, I was actually excited. I'd heard rumors about the place's reputation, of course--but I had no idea it was like this. My first month here, a handful of people signed up. Only one or two actually worked out with me. Nobody lost weight. And that's pretty much the way it's been for the past two years."

"God," said Lisa, absentmindedly plaiting her dark brown ringlets. "How frustrating for you. Do you have any idea what's made people in this town so...odd?"

"Well, I'm not sure," said Cody. "I've tried to find a straightforward history of this place. Why it split from North Barkalow, and everything else. All I can figure out, though, is that in the teens, when the government drove all the fast food joints out of business...it didn't drive them out of South Barkalow, and the Obesity Epidemic continued to spread here."

"But that doesn't make sense," Lisa protested. "Why would the government shut down these restaurants everywhere else? And how would these chains continue to function after being limited to one or two stores?" She took his hand, as if by impulse. "You must have heard more than that."

"N--not really," said Cody. Great, she thought. He was lying. She must be losing her touch, she thought--or else he was really scared of something. She would have to play the damsel in distress.

"Cody," she said, now brazenly taking his hand with both of hers,"I'm seriously worried. My job just transferred me here, too, and I really don't want to end up like one of these heifers. What do you know that's kept you from...you know...going the same way they have? I don't wanna get fat!"

"Neither did Grace," Cody muttered.
13332121.title: Interview Cody

133321211.content:
"Who?"

Cody sighed. "You'd better step into my office."

Grace, Cody explained, in low tones--at times, almost crying--had been his girlfriend. He showed her a picture of a stunning girl with straw-colored hair, posing with him on a mountaintop. Cody was surprised and impressed that Cody had ever been able to bag a girl of this caliber, even if he did have hair at the time. Originally, he said, when he had moved to South Barkalow, she'd moved with him. "I'd met her when she was in one of my yoga classes up North. But this place changed her." Cody went on to explain that he was a very strict vegan--he only ever went to one supermarket, and prepared all his meals at home. Grace had always been health-conscious, but once she got a job with a local law firm, it had been very difficult to continue eating exactly as Cody did.

"She started having lunches out," he said, quietly. "Her coworkers would all go out for lunch, and she didn't want to be the only one in the office, eating lunch all by herself." I made it a policy never to eat anywhere that serves animals. Just a personal choice, I guess," he said, in a tone that betrayed that he felt quite superior to most people. "Anyway, after a few weeks at work, she started to change. That food worked on her like a drug. Before I knew it, she wasn't even eating dinner at home. 'I can afford to eat out,' she'd say, before joining her new girlfriends. 'I have a real job.' After a few months...she wasn't Grace anymore. She was...unrecog-unrecognizable."

"You dumped her for getting fat?"

Cody sniffled. "No, not really...we just grew apart. All she wanted to do anymore was eat. All my hobbies had involved yoga, meditation and keeping fit. We had nothing to talk about anymore. And no, I wasn't all that attracted to her anymore, either."

Lisa tried not to sound annoyed. "So that just confirms the simplest theory, then--that the unregulated fast food joints are making people here fatter."

"Not--not exactly," Cody whispered. "The first two weeks she ate out with the girls, she said she only had the salad. No dressing, even. I know she was telling the truth, because they all gave her a hard time about it. She'd come home upset that she didn't fit in. I'd always ask her why she wanted to fit in, then she would laugh with me and we'd make fun of the other women's weight and stuff. I know that sounds mean, but you don't know what it's like to feel like an outsider where you live. Laughing at the people here was a way for us to cope. Anyway, yeah, she made it a policy to only eat the salads. But all the same, every night she would want to go out to eat more and more. She'd try lines like, "We never go anyplace nice," but I could tell that it was eating at a restaurant that she wanted--not a date. It was almost as if--"

Lisa leant in. "Almost as if what, Cody?" she whispered, doing her best to sound impressed and shocked.

"Almost as if," Cody whispered back, "they were putting something in those salads, in all the food...some chemical, like nicotine or something, to get people to crave anything at all at those restaurants."

Lisa leaned back and laughed. "But that sounds crazy. And she could have just kept having the salad, then, to get her fix."

"Shut up!" Cody whispered, harshly--evidently afraid. "Sorry," he whispered again, "but I've seen too many weird things around here. It all really started to affect Grace after her company retreat. They went out to the South Barkalow harbor together, as a team-building exercise. I'd never heard of a law firm doing that, but she'd told me it was mandatory. When she came back, she had changed. There was this new, hungry look in her eyes all the time. That's when she started going "out with the girls" in the evenings, too. I'd come home and find pizzas and barbecue ribs and apple pies in the fridge." Cody shuddered.

"Initially, she realized what she was doing to herself, and asked me to help her get back on track. We did yoga together, daily--she was my only customer at the time. But it wasn't taking. The weight just started to pile on, despite everything we were doing. Two pounds, one week. Five, the next. Then seven. Then ten. Finally, she had me hypnotize her to get to the bottom of it--yes, alternative preventative medicine does include a few classes in hypnotherapy, believe it or not--but nothing that she said made sense.

When I'd gotten her into a trance state, I asked her why she felt she was eating so much. She started saying really strange things, then, like, 'To join my sisters.' I asked her who her sisters were, and she said something about the seaside, and needing to go there--I could only assume she was referring to the harbor. Then she said something that gave me the chills. She said--she said--"I need to make him happy. To swim out to him. He is waiting." She wouldn't explain who he was. I never told her what she had said to me while she was under. After a while, she stopped working out. Then we stopped talking. Eventually, she just moved out. She didn't give me a reason, and I didn't ask her for one. There was no explosive fight. It was just like she...she forgot about me..."

Now this was trippy, thought Lisa. Of course, more than likely, this poor little man was a crazy health nut who had smoked a few too many joints in college. She could understand why the bombshell in the picture would have forgotten about him.

"You might think I'm crazy," whispered Cody. "But ask yourself this...why is everyone in this town so unfriendly--why do they act so weird? If there's nothing more going on than unregulated, dried up old fast food chains, why are we pretty much invisible to them? Before you dismiss me, also, there's another thing you should see. Go to the beach. But I'd wait until night to do that. You don't want to let anyone see that you're there."

1333212111.content:
That night, Lisa was surprised at how little time it took to get to the beach. She had also been surprised, that day, at how little traffic there actually was at rush hour, despite the fact that South Barkalow was the size of a small city. "Where are they all?" she'd asked herself. During the day, she'd tried to talk to a few of the corpulent residents, but--just as Cody had said--they seemed not to even see her. She decided she'd just make her way to the bay after the sun set. She wasn't about to wait longer, as she didn't have any particular desire to stay the night in this town. Anyway, it wasn't like the people here even seemed to see her when she talked to them--she had a pretty good feeling that no one would notice her at the beach. She was ridiculously hungry, not having dared to eat at any of the restaurants after Cody's story. She walked East, away from the setting sun. Within a few blocks, the lawns began to get sandier, the blocks flatter. She could hear seagulls. At length, the skyline stopped, and she began to hear the sound of surf and smell salt. Weird as South Barkalow was, she thought, at least their beaches were like every other. She suppressed the urge to run over the wide wooden bridge that rose over the dunes, seeming to lead to the sky itself.

But when she mounted the bridge, and looked out at the bay, her jaw dropped.

She had seen, at various times in her life, nature documentaries examining the habits of manatees and walruses--how they tended to lay themselves on rocky beaches during the day, sunning themselves, and filling the whole rocky beach with their blubbery, ungainly bodies that remained awkward and vulnerable until they dragged themselves to the shore and plunged into the brine. So it was here, but with people. She had never seen a beach so full of people. And she had never seen such enormous, manatee-like people on any beach. Many of them had fallen asleep while tanning before the sunset. Others simply lounged, on blankets, or on sand, apparently too tired to haul their fleshy selves out of the sand and go home. There were so many of them that their bodies were almost touching.

But then...if it was due to laziness that they were still out here...why were none of them talking? Indeed, the beach, here, despite being full of people was as silent as the town had been. She also noticed, with a shock, that those who were awake were gazing out to sea. She followed their eyes, and saw that there were even more of them floating in the ocean. And unless her eyes misled her (completely possible in the half-light), the floating ones were far, far bigger than any of those on the shore--who were in turn bigger than anyone she had seen in the town.

Suddenly, she heard voices behind her. On a crazy whim, she jumped under the bridge and into the scratchy weeds that grew beneath it--and just in the nick of time. The bridge began to groan under new footsteps, and by and by she saw a stream of people slowly and ceremoniously marching from over it, down to the beach. These people were also rather hefty, but not nearly so big as the men and women whose corpulent bodies littered the sand--many of whom, she now saw, were not even wearing swimsuits. Nevertheless, the bridge over her creaked so terribly that she ground her teeth, worried that it wouldn't hold. Lisa took out the binoculars she'd purchased that day for exactly this purpose. It was a full moon, thank God, with a clear sky, or else she would not have been able to make out much at all of the following scene.

The newcomers were all wearing uniforms of various kinds, and wheeling concession carts. With a start, she realized they must have been the workers at the fast food places, for the carts were decorated with the logos. They began to distribute the boxes once they reached the beach, putting them in the plump hands of the half- or fully-naked loungers, who now surged toward them--exactly as hungry animals would. Her she imagined them barking like seals, but if they spoke, they must have been whispering. Each of them was given a few boxes--two or three--before the carts moved down the beach toward harder sand. At length, most of the feeders came to the sea itself, where the fattest of the group continued to bob up and down in the water. There was a strange, unearthly cry, as of singing, and the uniformed men and women took even more boxes out of their carts, and began throwing them at the singers. They were eerily accurate, despite being so clearly out of shape, and when each of the naked, enormous singers received their supper, they stopped, taking burgers, chicken or fries in their soggy, swollen hands, and wolfing them down.

Lisa was lost for words. What was this?

One of the bathers, her mouth packed full of food as her face was packed full of chins, was moving a good deal more than the others. She seemed to be having a bit of trouble floating, despite the fact that she had even more buoyant flab on her frame than most of the other bathers. Lisa felt a sense of deja vu. Had she seen her before that day? Her mostly-wet hair was straw-colored, and hung past her enormous and plump shoulders. She had no trace of a neck. No, Lisa was sure she had seen her before, maybe in a picture...

It suddenly, horribly dawned on Lisa that this was Grace, Cody's ex-girlfriend. At the same time she realized this, she saw that the water around Grace was being stirred up, as if with a school of fish, a dolphin or a shark. At once, Grace began to have even more difficulty staying above the water, as if something besides her weight was pulling her down. This seemed to surprise the otherwise oblivious eater at first, and she came, momentarily, out of her trance. Lisa saw her look down at herself, then look back up, a glimmer of horror in her eyes at what she had become (Lisa's binoculars were really quite good). The blubbery former beauty splashed half-heartedly, as if to stay afloat. Then, as quickly as the moment of lucidity came, it vanished, and Grace stopped struggling--reaching instead for a piece of pie that floated next to her, and shoving as much of it as possible into her mouth, almost as a last meal. Chewing it, she was at peace again, and she seemed to look directly at Lisa, across the intervening beach, as a contented smile spread across her fat, full face. Then, with a sudden scream of--unmistakably, of delight, Lisa thought--the girl who had been Grace was pulled down beneath the waves. Suddenly, Lisa heard other screams of the same kind, and lowered her binoculars to see some of the hugest bathers, who were furthest out, disappearing beneath the waves as well. Once all the screams had ceased, the others in the water began to swim further out, in order to get to the food, Lisa supposed, that the ones who had been taken hadn't managed to finish. Meanwhile, the moon-bathers who were closest to the shore, got in the water and began to float.

This was all a bit too much for Lisa. "What the fu--" she began, but was interrupted.

"I might ask you the same question," came a deep and feminine voice above Lisa.

Lisa recognized the well-dressed and important-looking woman who had walked past her earlier that day. She also recognized that she was in a world of trouble.

What should Lisa do?

Lisa takes a seat in Maria's car. It's bright red, and the driver's seat is extra large.

"So, nice car", Lisa said awkwardly. It was the first compliment she could think of at that time.

"Thanks, it used to be my dad's, but he ditched it and got a new one." At the mention of her father, the boyfriend quickly looks uncomfortable.

The drive to her house, though, is short- Lisa was sure that the proximity to restaurants couldn't have been a coincidence, and, through a brief, if Maria- dominated conversation, she found out that the closeness actually increased property value. An interesting piece of information, she thought. Well, a relatively boring piece of information actually. But, hey, I'm hardly writing this report for quality.

Once they arrived, Lisa noticed that the house was impressive, too.

"What do your parents do for a living?", asked Lisa, when they got into what was probably the family room.

Maria was already walking to the kitchen. "My dad's a big-time employee at the bank here," she said, opening what looked like an oversized bag of chips, and pouring them into a bowl.

"What are those?" Lisa hadn't seen any bag that size for snacks before.

"Cookies. Want some?"

Lisa looked in the bowl, and she saw that the bag was indeed full of chocolate chip cookies. Not mini-size ones, either. It was a snack bag of maybe 40 normal-sized ones! Something about that disgusted her- not least because of the calorie content of such a meal. But, disgust aside, she was still starving. "Hell yeah!" Lisa took a handful and greedily wolfed it down.

They were delicious, especially for store-bought eats. Rich, and chocolatey goodness!

After realizing what she'd done, she wasn't sure whether to be more ashamed of her gluttony or her manners. But looking up, Maria didn't seem too fazed. This was, of course, normal for this town.

"Alright, not so fast", Maria said gingerly. "They're mostly for my boyfriend, so don't eat too many, ok?

Lisa suddenly realized part of the reason that she was so creeped out.

"So what's your boyfriend's name? I don't think he's said."

The boy opened his mouth to speak, but Maria shoved a cookie down his throat. "Now now, sweetie, you know you're meant to be eating, right? Sorry. His name's Chip."

Lisa was a little relieved.

"So what do you people read? Like is there a town newspaper?"

"Oh yeah," said Maria, looking at Chip, silently demanding him to eat more. "it's called 'Chewing the Fat'. All the latest gossip and stuff. Here, there's a copy on the table if you want to read it."

Lisa looked where Maria had pointed, and found a colourful magazine.

"Mhm. So, Chip. Why did you come here?

Chip was about to put down his next cookie, but Maria stopped him. "How many times to I have to tell you this?" She looked at Lisa.
"He never seems to learn. Now darling, just keep stuffing your little face. If you want to talk, just talk with your mouth full, like normal people. Like, say, my brother. How else are you going to keep putting on weight?"

Chip showed visible disgust at the prospect, but he caved into Maria's pressure.

"Wall, my barends mobed here, ash I shed, cubblob monfs 'go, an'..."

Lisa listened with pity as the boy could hardly stop. She only wrote in her notebook what she could hear, and even then just so that he would feel less bad about it.

"I see." An obvious lie. "Listen, I'd love to continue the interview, but I'm famished, and Chip over here's eaten all of the cookies."

"Oh, that's no problem! You can have supper with us!"

Lisa considered. "I'm not sure."

"You can think about it, I'm off to do something. Shouldn't take too long."

With that, Maria left the room, motioning for Chip to follow.

Lisa took a look at that magazine she'd been curious to check out. She looked at some of the headlines, to write them down later.

"Buses- the new way to go?"

"Who's hot and who's not- the large, lovely ladies of fashion"

"Why you might be losing money right now!"

"Tips on padding your waistline over the Summer"

"Best and worst beach bodies"

Lisa found that many of the bodies did look in fact quite impressive, and some were actually disgusting. Flipping through the magazine to the article, she noticed that, as she should have suspected, the huge bodies were "best" and the slender girls "worst".

Overall, she spurned the shallowness of the magazine. "Only in this crazy town", she thought.

Before long, she touched the end of the pool. Her challenger lay roughly 12 metres behind her.

"Looks like we have a winner!"

The referee held Lisa's arm up from the water. There were cheers, although perhaps not so enthusiastic given that sports weren't big here. Lisa smiled. It felt good to be the thinnest person here.

"Kiss goodbye to your nice slim body there. You're not going to see it again!"

Thinking about her body reminded Lisa of that nightmare. She shuddered at the thought of getting anywhere near as fat as these people. Looking around, she noticed that Maria and Chip weren't in the pool. She put on a towel and went looking for them.

After searching for a few minutes, her stomach growled. It felt like she hadn't eaten in days.

She went over to the almost mandatory snack bar. When it was her turn in line (which took some time), she gazed up at the menu, and fished some bills out of her wallet.

"I'd like 2 chili cheese hotdogs, and a large poutine, with a large coke. Oh, and a mini-pizza."

"That'll be $7.95 please."

Oh the bargains this place had. Lisa put her bills back and dropped some coins down on the counter. She then sat down at a table, waiting for food, and got out her notebook. "Food is a fraction of the price- cheap to make, and in such high demand that it's profitable at almost any price, as long as it's affordable."

"Ah, there you are. Hiya!" Maria's singsong voice came from another table, stacked with food. Chip walked with Maria to Lisa's table, and patted her on the back.

"That was great! Nice swimming there!"
"It was pretty good. A little unladylike, but still impressive."

Lisa wasn't sure whether to take Maria's words as a compliment or insults, but she assumed they were at least positive. "Thanks. I, uh, practiced a lot when I was a kid."

Maria stared at her, as if to disbelieve the idea. "Ahhh..."

"What?"

"Is that why you're so skinny?"

Lisa blushed. It was flattering, even if she was looking at her strangely.
"Well, it's part of the reason. That and limiting what I eat."
Maria narrowed her eyes and smirked. "Limiting?"

Lisa's meal arrived. The hotdogs were enormous, over half a foot long each. The poutine was smothered in cheese and gravy. Even the mini pizza was only slightly half the size of a normal one.

"Well, mostly. I figured I'd treat myself for winning."
"As far as I can tell, you hardly stop eating."

Lisa was halfway done her first hot dog, fast eater that she was. Maria was right. But she was hungry enough that it didn't matter. Besides, she had a high metabolism, and she could diet anything she gained off.

"I'm starving!"

"Ok, no need to get defensive. In fact, I admire your appetite. As a matter of fact..."

"...Kat?"

She took a swig of some kind of milkshake.

"No."

"Oh. So, how goes finding a new girlfriend? Work out well for you?"

"Well...no."

"Surprise surprise."

"So do you live here now?"

Lisa lowered her voice.

"So, how goes the diet? Didn't go too well, I see? Did you get this fat, then come here because you would fit in? Or was all the food around here just too much for you?"

Lisa looked at her in disbelief.
"You used to be skinny, athletic, and hot. Then you didn't work out as hard, you stopped dieting, and got chunky."

"It's just a shame that you let your figure go to waste."

She got up and stood up in the light. She was just a little less than medium height, with short dark hair. She was dressed casually, in a sweatshirt and sweatpants that were big even on her. As she got out of her seat, her legs moved differently than normal. Her thighs were thicker and she now had a huge prodigious belly. While she used to be flat-chested, she was considerably more buxom, although her clothes made it hard to initially tell. Her arms were thick and doughy. Not a trace of muscle was visible. Lisa thought that her face actually looked even younger than before. She now sported a double chin.

Yells of "No!" and the like echoed through the room, and there were even a few wolf-whistles. Lisa was slightly pissed. She didn't like that her ex getting more attention than her, and she definitely didn't like that people were looking at her like that, even if Lisa didn't find her attractive.

"See? In this town, you have dignity! You can be happy at any size, and no one's going to look down on you for it! Besides, most people here don't mind a few pounds on someone." She looked at Lisa, head turned slightly. "Say, you know, you got awfully mad when I gained just a little weight..."

Most of them wouldn't eat that much regularly."

Lisa froze.

"And believe me, it's starting to show." She poked Lisa's gut. "But you eat as much as you like. You're a growing girl."

"Hey, you know, you're really helping with Chip's diet."

Lisa didn't know how to respond.

141211212111211212211211.content:
Lisa walked down the road, looking for somebody who might not be eating and thus would have some time to talk. It was an inordinately long search, but she did manage to find somebody. He wore a baseball cap and sunglasses, and only part of his face was visible. He was tall, wearing a red jacket, and most of his weight was carried in his paunch.

"Yeah, the library's on 1355 Davidson. You just take two rights from here, and then it's near Frank's Furters."

Lisa wrote this information down hurriedly. "Thank you for your time." She then ran to the library to see if it was still open. Fortunately, closing time was 2 hours from now. She entered, wondering what was inside.

The library had a green floor and cream-coloured wallpaper. Bookshelves were relatively few. A father read some book to his three kids, something about a fox. Nothing she'd ever heard of. A small group of teens dressed in black clothes sat reading comics. Lisa furtively took a glance. The artwork wasn't conventional western style, nor was it manga or the like. It was some distinct style.

Lisa took a look at some books on the shelves. After a while of idle browsing, she found a book that she liked when she was younger. She flipped through it. As she was reading, she noticed something peculiar. At one point in the book, when the protagonist puts on clothes, she's described as a size 36. Lisa wondered how well she had actually read the book in the first place. She looked for another mention of weight. Again, she found that the protagonist was 328 pounds. This was definitely off. Lisa was sure that she was thinner. But....the book was the same! It looked the same, same title, same cover....she put it down and scribbled in her notebook to check up on the books.

She proceeded to the librarian. He was quite young. He wore a grey, smooth shirt and sported reading glasses. His skin was soft and pale, and his hair was very dark, but reasonably well-kept. He was a blob of a boy, easily 500 pounds. He looked at Lisa intently.

"Yes? How can I help?"

"Um, I'd like to know if there are any books on this town's history."

"Oh, a tourist." His initial interest in this newcomer faded. "Go to non-fiction, section 517."

LIsa felt a bit brushed off, but went there anyway. She selected the largest, most comprehensive work in the section, and opened it up. She read quickly, skipping over what seemed unimportant, for there was a lot to cover.

South Barkalow...founded near the end of the 19th century. Lisa read with shock. Slavery, public hangings, a long list of hate crimes. The incriminating list resonated with dissonance to what she saw: a friendly, folksy, town that was almost progressive, in spite of its traditions and attitudes towards food. She saw a photograph of a witch trial (did they even do those then? Lisa was unsure whether this was normal for the day or specific to South Barkalow, and jotted down to look that up). A middle aged woman, falsely accused of cursing the populace. The people in the photo were thin- all of them. They wore expressions mean as wolves. Lisa thought that the convicted witch looked vaguely like the woman she dreamed of. But it seemed too old- they were thin, and for them to have noticed any curse, they would have to be larger. Assuming this person actually existed, perhaps she was a relative of the hanged witch. A mother or aunt, perhaps. But then, the question was not whether she was a witch, but what she did to the townsfolk.. it was all a puzzle.

Lisa read on. Thanks to a mix of activism and general changes to attitudes, the town gradually became more liberal. It abolished slavery and later quit using the death penalty, eventually rising up to similar standards as the rest of the "developed world". She flipped through photos. Thin, thin, thin....then, in the mid-60's, Lisa suddenly saw large amounts of obese citizens. The photo was dated 1966. Lisa jotted down the date and its significance. Fascinating! Perhaps the curse had something to it. Either way, now she knew when it started getting so fat. Definitely good to write about. She flipped to the index, looking for Rebecca Park.. She eventually found a picture of her.

She was of no modest size. She wore long brown hair (or at least it looked brown, it was a black and white photo), and had a jowly, puffed-up face. Her neck was almost nonexistent, engulfed by fat. All her features were engorged, her body a massive pear-shape. There was something dainty, almost pretty about her. Whatever it was, it wasn't complimented by her having to wear a large potato sack, which even then was stretched. Lisa looked at her in pity. She clearly was holding back sadness. She seemed young. Perhaps as young as 14 even, but she couldn't tell. A caption told that she was from a lower-class family. Lisa immediately wondered how she got so fat when she was so poor, but her wonder was dispelled just as quickly after reading that she had Prader-Willi syndrome, causing her to gain weight easily, and her family ate mostly beef and corn. She was bullied relentlessly, and mocked publicly for a long time in the town, gaining a sort of infamy.

Lisa read more about 1966. The weight gain was at least acknowledged, and the curse cited as a possible reason, noting the name of the mayor, Mack Harding, who was the first to be told. However, it was dismissed as a rumour. A few years later, a gradual event occurred- the public, more and more, became not just accepting of fat, but embracing it. By the 70s, slim people were stigmatized. It figured. They learned as much of a lesson as one could expect them to.

After jotting down the last of the details, Lisa put down the book. She'd spent a little more than an hour reading, and she had other things to find out. This library provided plenty of new topics, but which one to pick?

"Excuse me," Lisa nervously asked the librarian, "but some books here, they seem...different."

"Different? What do you mean?"

"Well...I read some of these books back in Pennsylvania. I think the characters were, ah, thinner. Did you notice that at all?"

The librarian looked at her like she'd told him the moon was made out of cheese.

"Can't say I do...I was born and raised here, anyway."

So not much progress from the librarian. Lisa took a look at other nonfiction books. Most of these were cookbooks, although there was a selection, it wasn't huge. She flipped through a cookbook that was uniquely South Barkalow's. Most of these recipes made her jaw drop. Deep-fried jumbo hot dogs covered in bacon wrapped inside a pancake, covered in chocolate? Quadruple cream cheese chocolate fudge cake? Fried banana marshmallow pie? Lisa wasn't sure whether they made her more disgusted or hungry. After all, given her appetite, she could eat any of these. She put it away. Such temptation couldn't be good.

She paced around the library, looking for someone to talk to about the books. She asked children and adults alike, but no one had any clue what she was talking about. She was about to give up on that topic when she heard a faint and covered sneeze. She looked around, unsure where it had came from. It sounded close. She checked around a bookshelf, and noticed a girl sitting up behind it.

She had red hair in a ponytail, and wore thin reading glasses. She loosely wore a blue jacket around a white shirt, and was wearing faded jeans. She glanced up at Lisa with wide green eyes. She had a very slight frame, with little fat at all showing.

"Yes?" she asked nervously.

"Oh, nothing. Just looking around, trying to figure out something."
Lisa was bothered by the silence. "So, uh, what are you reading?"

The girl flipped the cover of the book to show Lisa.

How to Gain Weight
By Dr. Maurice Cheswick

"Oh. Uh, I see. You're not from around here, are you?"

She shook her head.

"I came here last spring, from South Dakota."

"South Dakota? That's pretty far off, don't you think?"

"Yes. My father moved here as part of his business. He works in catering, and he's found good job opportunities here."

"Ah. You like it here?"

"No. Not really. I mean, most of the people are nice, and it's fine to live in, but...a lot of the girls at school pick on me for being skinny. Some of the boys too."

"Really? What grade are you in?"

"10."

Yikes. Body image problems that young...

"Hm. I wouldn't worry. A lot of people are jerks in the junior years of high school." Lisa looked at her. "Are you gaining weight because of them?"

"Partially."

"Partially?"

"I can't get a boyfriend or anything unless I gain weight."

"Oh, and how's that going?"

"I'm, um, single."

"I was more curious about the weight stuff."

"Not good, as you can see. I can hardly gain a pound."

"Really?" Lisa was becoming increasingly intrigued. "Even with all the junk food around for cheap?"

"Nope. Honestly, I don't have a very big appetite. Most of the food here makes me kind of sick."

Lisa paused, thinking.

"And the people around here, what do you think of them?"

"They're nice, generous, mostly, some are kind of good-looking...why do you need to know all this?"

"Well, I'm a reporter, doing an article on this town. That, and, I kind of want to help out. I'm not from here either, as you can see."

"Oh, um, thanks." The girl evidently wasn't sure what else to say.

"You know, you don't have to listen to them."

The girl turned her head upwards, curious. "What?"

"You don't need to gain weight. Look at you, you're young, pretty, you have lots going for you. Why'd you want to get fat just so that people will like you?" Lisa stood up straight and cleared her throat. "And, besides which, any friends worth having wouldn't want to mess with your health! Same for any boyfriend. Sooner or later, you'll meet a gentleman and he won't try to fatten you up like a pig just so he'll love you."

The girl blushed and smiled. It was a professionally done speech, Lisa thought, as she walked away.

"Wait!"

Lisa turned her head back.

"What are you trying to figure out?"

"Well, you look like a big reader."

She nodded.

"Have you ever noticed that the books here are...different?"

The girl paused. "Oh yes, I think I know what you're talking about."

"Why is that?"

"Well, there isn't much time, and I don't totally understand, but... do you have a sheet of paper?"

"Sure," said Lisa, taking a page from her notebook, and a pen from her pocket.

The girl scribbled down something. "Here, go to this address. Talk to the guy there, he'll know."

The library is closing in 5 minutes.

"Well, got to go. Thanks a lot."

"No problem. Hope you do well with your article."

Lisa walked out of the library, a confident smile on her lips. She went back to her hotel room. When she got there, she moaned as her belly rumbled loudly. Suddenly, she had an idea. She took out her wallet, and removed all the money except for $8. Now, she couldn't afford to overeat even if she wanted to! She fixed herself a large salad with low calorie vinaigrette, and a glass of milk.

She then took a taxi, which she realized was the same one as before when the cabby recognized her. "Hey, young lady. How goes your little investigation?"

"Good thanks. I need you to get me to here." She pulled out the address.

"Alright, I can do that. So, how's life treating you?"

"You wouldn't believe my luck."

"Oh?"

"Rather not talk about it."

"Fine, fine. Say, you look healthier. Have you put on weight?"

"Yes, as a matter of fact. 12 pounds to be precise."

"Haven't even been here a week. That's like more than 2 pounds a day! You must like the food here, huh?"

That wasn't really the reason per se, but she found it to be a large factor. "Yup."

"Most people who come here do. Mind you, if they're not too busy gawking that is."

After what felt like hours, cab stopped in a lonely, narrow road, away from most of the town. It was quiet here, and there were only a couple buildings.

"Here you are. Paradise lost!"

Lisa fished out the $6 fee. "Thanks."

"No problem." The cab sped off.

"This is ridiculous! There's nothing illegal about what goes on here!"

"Oh? Well, then, I suppose you might just show me. You know, just to avoid unnecessary trouble."

"Fine, fine!"

The man showed her into the building. It was poorly lit, and a humming noise could be easily heard. He opened a door, and motioned for Lisa to come inside.

Inside was a large computer. "Wow, where'd you get this?"

"Provided by the mayor."

"What's it do?"

"Well, I've programmed it to look through a database of all books that this town owns. We never use the actual books, just the text, which we keep on files. Anyway, this computer will look through all books containing at any point "thin" "fat" or any synonyms (which it has in its word bank) , any reference to weight or measurements of weight, and the word "size" when used within 200 words of any article of clothing or the word clothes, and then showing, through links to the pages and highlights, the word. Then, it's a simple matter of replacing the reference to weight with something less controversial to the town. See, watch."

Lisa watched. Some fantasy novel she hadn't read appeared on the list, along with it's picture and information. The man clicked on it, and some stats popped up.

Fat: 0
Synonyms: 5
Thin: 0
Synonyms: 2
Weight measurements: 0
Apparent clothing sizes: 0

He then clicked on "Synonyms" under "Fat". Another window popped up, going directly to page 163.

"Rhandel observed the troll. It was an ugly sight: a potbellied, distended creature, with grey skin covered in warts."

The man clicked on the highlighted red text, and replaced it:


"Rhandel observed the troll. It was an ugly sight: a skeletal, gangly creature, with grey skin covered in warts."

He then clicked the "next" button at the bottom of the page. The page changed to 212.

"'I refuse to marry that creep!', said princess Salvina. He' s ugly, porcine, and absolutely disgusting!"

Editing it, it became:

"I refuse to marry that creep! He' s ugly, gaunt, and absolutely disgusting!"

"Fervern had been feasting many days in the Southstorm palace, and he had grown quite plump for all the rich food."

"This doesn't need editing, because at this point there's no negative reference to weight." The man then saved the changes, exited out of the window, and opened up "Synonyms" under "thin"

He was brought instantly to page 49

"Salvina, Lexmus could tell, was a beautiful creature- she had a delicate, slender body, with supple skin..."

He rewrote it as:

"Salvina, Lexmus could tell, was a beautiful creature- she had a soft, delightfully corpulent body, with supple skin..."

"Oh, I think I get it!"

"Yeah, and I do this for every book that the town is thinking of approving."

"Wow, that's impressive!" Lisa said this earnestly. "But, what if you missed something?"

"Ah, that's the question, now. You see, the next step would be to write up all the changes made, perform a new search on the same book, and find all references to attractiveness, and then change it appropriately. Then, I look over my notes, and I look up the character that was changed, and then I edit each description of that character's body to fit in. Then I can list the book as approved."

"That's quite a lot of work! What's the point of all this?"

"The point? The point is so that people here can read books knowing that they're not going to be offended. When you've got a population that's almost all obese, you take extra steps. It's part of a whole plan made by the mayor."

"The mayor? He's the one behind all of this? Is he also changing the shows?"

"Yup. He's hiring people to change all pieces of media entering the town so that the town can be comfortable watching or reading anything without too much controversy."

"And all this is legal?"

"Yes! It' s all incognito deals between the town and publishers and networks. As for theatre, they just use local actors, and anything's fine."

"All this sounds expensive. Where is this town getting the money?"

"Well, most of it's from tourism and taxes on the food industry."

"Ah...that explains a lot."

"I suppose it does."

"Well, thanks for your time. Sorry for the trouble, you know, delaying that brilliant work of yours."

"No no, I guess it can't be helped. No huge problem."

"Can I write about what goes on?"

"Hm? I suppose you can mention it. But please be indirect. Definitely don't mention me, ok?"

"Alright."

Lisa walked out of the building, after finishing her notes. This was working really well! She walked back for a while, then took a passing bus. She was less self-conscious about being watched now. She got off near her hotel, then walked in, and went back to her room. Once again she was hungry, and made herself some pasta. Lisa woke up, dazed and almost giddy. She got up, a smile on her face, and put on a relatively large red shirt, and stretch pants. Naturally, she was hungry again. But, she simply ordered some toast with low-fat margarine, and a bowl of fruit, with some milk. The waitress looked at her, as if to ask "Seriously?", but Lisa pretended not to notice. When she finished her breakfast, Lisa got to work typing on her computer.

"South Barkalow

America's Fattest Town"

She wrote up what she had seen, first contrasting the various types of restaurants (and related commercialism), and noting the lack of exercise. She mentioned, of course, that snacks were provided everywhere, even pushed on the residents, and there was a stigma on being thin equivalent to the stigma on obesity in the rest of America. She decided to emphasize that fact, making sure to allude to the case of Rebecca Park.

When she had finished, which was around noon, she thought that it was masterful, at least for a rough copy. But it was time for lunch. She put another 5 dollars in her wallet, and went out.

She decided to go to the Nuclear Submarine. She was starving, again, but she only had the money for two footlong submarine sandwiches and a chocolate milk (this order was great for Lisa's waistline, since she would have eaten at least double that on a whim). She had lean meats and vegetables. As she looked at the preparation, she noticed, to her dismay, the sandwich-maker slathering on mayonaise. She consoled herself, noting that she had eaten only a small breakfast and could abstain from future snacking.

She ate with gusto, wiping off mayonaise that dripped everywhere from the sandwiches. A morbidly obese family, eating even more per person, stared at her as if she was a bizarre new species. Yeah, you just keep staring, she thought, walking out through the door.

Lisa then went jogging on an empty lane, the only one in town, bought years ago, and in disarray. She ran for an hour, then decided to rest in the shade.

"You been working out again, huh?"

"Wuthemawho?" Lisa scrambled to her feet, startled and only just noticing the imposing figure next to her. She rolled over. "What the hell are you doing here?"

"Public property."

"Ok, Kat, look. We're through. Stop following me!"

"Sure. You just seemed lonely, that's all."

Lisa narrowed her eyes. "How did you know where I was?"

"Just tagged along to your place."

"Seriously?"

"Yup."

"Shit that's creepy."

"Is it?" Kat appeared indifferent. There was a silence. "So, you're just staying to write this article?"

"Yeah. Why?"

"Pity. You could always stay for longer."

"I could..." Lisa said through grit teeth.

"Am I bothering you? I could always go."

"No, that's fine. Stay if you want, I guess."

"Ah. So, when do you leave? Soon, I s'pose?"

"Yeah. Today's my second last day on the job. I'm almost done."

"Ah. Well, I have stuff to do. I'll be off then."

Lisa breathed a sigh of relief. It was getting both more and less comfortable to be around Kat. She picked up her stuff, which wasn't much, and killed time on a walk, several onlookers noting her legs with silent but well-expressed disgust. It was mid-afternoon already, and Lisa felt hungry, despite having not enough cash to fuel her binges. She was proud of herself for sticking to such a rigorous and well thought-out diet plan. She proceeded straight to her hotel room, being already bored of the mostly eventless and draining day, and got to rewriting the article, replacing choppy bits with clearer paragraphs, and being more concise in her wording. By supper, she couldn't resist her hunger, and made herself a large plate of pasta with cheese from the ingredients in her room. She then proceeded to entertain herself by playing through various videos she had stored on her computer.

She decided to retire to bed early before she got hungry again. Tomorrow's the last day, she thought to herself happily. I can go back to Pennsylvania after, and go back with the usual friends. Somehow, sleep came easier since the dream. She wasn't sure why. Was the dream real, or was it just all the food getting to her? It felt very real, but many dreams do. She went to sleep pondering the question, half-believing that she truly was cursed.

The last day in South Barkalow...

Lisa woke up somewhat early but still refreshed. Once again she had a light breakfast, just some bacon and eggs. She only made enough to fill her up, and then it was time to get back to work.

She called over Maria. When she got there, it was already lunchtime.

"Ah, sorry I'm late!" Maria said as she came in, arms full of bags and boxes of food. " I was just treating Chip to a whole chicken in gravy. Here, I brought you some food."
She put a brown paper bag on the kitchen counter. Lisa looked inside. A few slices of pizza. She touched them. Still warm. So, she immediately gobbled them down. "Thanks! Now, ah, if you don't mind, we have some work to do."

Lisa washed off her hands as Maria took a look at the article.

"It's interesting, I'll give you that," Maria said sweetly. "But, it's a little weird."

After showing her the specific oddities, Lisa assured her repeatedly that she didn't mind. "Uh, that's, part of the paper's tone." A half-truth. It was just written from an outsider's perspective, as Lisa duly noted. The work was fairly dull, but after Maria proofread and edited it, it looked good enough to send in.

Lisa went to her wallet and fished out a few bills. "Here," she said, "$35 for your help."

"Oh, it's nothing," Maria said, making more clear than necessary how flattered she was, "we'll call it practice and a favour."

Lisa silently put the money away. She didn't really want any if she was to be out anyways. Too much temptation....

"Hey, you want to have some of this stuff? It's really good!" Maria yelled over from the table, enthusiastically.

"Um, no thanks. I'm, uh, on a diet."

Maria gave her a shocked look. "That's not like you at all!"

"Well, normally I don't eat much...."

"Oh, I see. Afraid all the sweets are going to pad your hips?" She grinned incredulously.

Lisa reddened. "Uh, sorta. I'm more worried about this gut though."

She patted her belly. Maria narrowed her eyes.

Even by typical standards, it would be a huge stretch to say Lisa had anything like a gut. At most her belly was slightly convex. Muscles were only slightly padded. As a matter of fact, her weight gain had only pushed her a couple of pounds past an average weight.

"Don't say that, you're very pretty! If anything, a little weight would look good on you!"

Lisa took the compliments well, but the last sentence, she thought, would have had more influence on her if the speaker hadn't been over 200 pounds overweight (during a chat, Lisa had learned that she was 386 pounds), as well as busying herself eating half a dozen donuts in one sitting (the contents, Lisa saw, of one of the boxes).

"Come on, you know you can't resist some of this pecan pie! It's my own special recipe. Chip can't get enough of it."

Then again, she thought, Chip couldn't get enough of anything. Lisa wasn't sure as to whether the quality needed to be that good.

Lisa winced. "Uh, ok. I'll try some thanks."

Lisa's skepticism over the taste of Maria's treats instantly faded. Rich caramel, crunchy nuts, the best pastry she'd ever had...

Before she knew it, she was thoroughly bloated. "Mmmm! That stuff's awesome."

"I'm glad you like it that much! I knew some goodies would get your appetite back!"

Lisa looked down, surprised. She'd eaten the whole thing.

"No need to be embarrassed, sweetie! I can always make more! In fact..." Maria checked her watch. "Oh! I need to be back! Well, you can keep the food. Except for this, it's Chip's supper." She grabbed the largest box. Lisa protested, but Maria was insistent, and quickly went through the door, wishing Lisa good day and good luck.

"Great. How am I supposed to get rid of all this food?" Lisa wondered. Then, it hit her. A second line of defense!

"FREE FOOD!" Lisa yelled through the streets, after she was sure Maria was gone. It was hardly a minute before the food was totally taken by gluttonous inhabitants.

She had only kept some chicken and a stir fry, which she had for supper after more jogging. Kat wasn't there, or at least she wasn't noticeable. She spent most of the rest of the day packing her things for the road.

After she had gotten everything, she walked over to the bus station that led outside of town. The same one she had entered from. A man that looked three times as wide as her gave her a weird look as he walked over. "Well," she thought. "No more weird looks when I get out of here." She then walked confidently and cheerfully, until she tripped on a crack in the sidewalk.

She struggled to get up. After roughly a minute of unceremonious squirming (which drew even more attention, including a few stares), she pushed herself backwards a little, and then slowly stood up, brushing herself off. She then proceeded over, carefully avoiding the crack, but she couldn't seem to go further. Her eyes widened. She tried again. No use. She was only about 30 steps from getting to the bus station, but no matter how hard she tried, she couldn't proceed. Her body just wouldn't let her go in that direction. Finally, she gave up, furious. She asked Maria for a ride.

Maria went by in her red car, Chip in shotgun. He was eating from a huge box of pastries, all full of cream, some with jam, some with chocolate. He could hardly stop for a moment, and when he did, Maria pushed him. "So, Lisa, what's wrong?"

"It's, uh, nothing. I just wanted to stay with you guys for a while, if that's alright." A total lie, but Lisa didn't dare say the real reason, for fear of being committed.

"Oh, sure! We'd love to have you over again! For how long?"

"Uh, I don't know. Can we talk about it later?"

"Sure!"

So they sped over to Maria's. "Can I use the computer?"

"Of course!"

Lisa went over to an enormous chair, presumably that of Maria's father. Just imagining how big that guy must be, and how Chip had to get that fat...Lisa already felt sorry for him. But she had business. She plugged in the USB containing her story, and emailed it to her coworker.

"Uh, this is my report on South Barkalow (attached), finished. I've had some difficulties with getting back, so I'll be taking an extended vacation here. Please make sure the boss knows, and that he emails me any future assignments.

Thanks;

Lisa Boytise"

She then sent it, took the USB back, and took a rest in a huge couch. "So Lisa," Maria said, walking over, holding Chip in her hands like a doll. "How long are you going to stay?"

"Well..." she looked at their faces. Surely she couldn't tell the full story. They'd never believe it even if she did. She thought for a minute.

Well she did tell the whole story. Most of it anyways.

"An-and I think I'm cursed! And I just can't leave her, no matter how hard I try!" Lisa sobbed.

"Oh...that's terrible." Maria gave a sympathetic look. "I didn't know, I-"

"No, it's fine. I just need somewhere to live now that I can't live in my own home."

"Sure! We have an extra room and everything." Maria perked up. "And don't worry about eating us out of house and home, either. As I'm sure you noticed, we're rich, and we all eat loads anyways. Even your eating isn't as much as my dad's."

So Lisa spent the next few days living with the Cobblers (as such was their surname).
